Mathematics of Machine Learning

This course focuses on statistical learning theory, which roughly means understanding the amount of data required to achieve a certain prediction accuracy. The two fields of statistics and machine learning share common goals, but they have evolved differently. Statistics was already a fully developed scientific discipline by 1920, while machine learning emerged later. Machine learning requires knowing the probability distribution from which the data is drawn, often with unknown parameters that have physical meanings.

Key Concepts:

  • Difference between Statistics and Machine Learning
  • Understanding Data Requirements for Prediction Accuracy
  • Importance of Modeling in Machine Learning
  • partial knowledge of distribution
  • no-free-lunch theorem
  • trade-off between estimation and approximation
Machine Learning Statistical Learning Theory Data Analysis Probability Distribution Maximum Likelihood Estimation estimation error classifiers statistical learning theory concentration inequalities
Data Science Intermediate
